Fields.DialogueText: Hello, Nashville. You look...
Use your words.
I think the word is "ecstatic." You look ecstatic this morning. Anything I should know about?
Nothing special, Captain. I'm just riding high off of that command performance earlier.
I still get messages from the other ships applauding me or asking for an encore.
Oh, yeah? Have you given any thought to the idea of putting on another show?
Not just yet, I think. It was really something, don't get me wrong. Something I didn't know I'd feel out here. But I would rather spend some time focused on the war.
Or, I mean, on my place in the war... and in the Fleet. Thinking about the war as a whole is just depressing.

Fields.MenuText: What would you like your place in the Fleet to be? You already have an important role.
The war is not a heartwarming topic to ponder, but I am glad you are considering it in some capacity.
Are you interested in expanding what you do for the Fleet? That is something we can certainly work on.

Fields.DialogueText: Not sure yet, Captain. But I'm learning a lot about what people see in me. Mostly they can shove their opinions, but it's on my mind.
Captain, everyone in the Fleet thinks about it in "some" capacity. We're actually fighting it, if you'll notice.
Yes, I think I am, Captain. But I need some more time to decide how.
Well, whatever you decide, be sure to let me know and I'll help however I can.
Think you're up to it?
@BATTLE
You picked me to be up to it. I trust your judgment.
*ALARM*
Famous last words.
Fame's not so bad.
It ain't. But you gotta be alive to enjoy it, and it's better shared.
Nashville! I was hoping to see you around here. I'm glad the celebrity life isn't too overwhelming.
Do you think there's any chance I could sit in on your next practice session?
Probably not, Captain. I've had to start hiding them or the crew won't leave me alone.
And there are fellas from other crews sneaking on all the time, hoping to catch a glimpse of me.
I was half hoping this would be a one and done sort of deal, Captain, and now I can't get away.
I suppose this is sort of my fault, isn't it? I did convince you to perform, after all.
You think, Captain? This is not what I had in mind when you floated the idea to me.

Fields.MenuText: All right, I'll try to get the other crews to stop harassing you.
Maybe we'll need to see about making you a full time performance vessel.
I appreciate that you aren't just tossing them overboard, or that I haven't heard about it if you are.

Fields.DialogueText: You'd better. I'm not much for performing if it ain't on a stage.
Don't even joke about that, Captain. I'll pull up anchor and light out for the territories before that happens.
You're welcome, Captain. Don't think I haven't thought about hefting 'em into the drink.
It seems like your newfound fame will have to wait for a bit.
@ALARM
@BATTLE
Those poor sailors. They might spend their whole career aboard me without so much as an autograph.
Nashville, I have a question that I think you can help me with.
That sounds suspiciously like you have a job for me, Captain.
Well, aren't you prescient. Some of the folks on land have called in a favor, and I think we're up to it.
Please don't tell me it's another concert. I don't think I could live with myself if it is.
No, actually. It's a transport of cargo. Specifically human cargo.
And you came to me because I have experience with such things, I assume?
Exactly. The Americans want us to transport a band into Europe to do some shows for the troops.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think you're up for something like that?
How soon can we have additional berthing made ready on the ship?
We can turn it down if you think it will be too disruptive. Let another ship handle it...

Fields.DialogueText: I think I'm more suited than anyone else in the Fleet. Might even be nice to play with them, if they know their stuff.
Easy enough, Captain. It might be a little snug, depending on how many we're bringing.
I can handle it, Captain, and it will cause me fewer problems than anyone else.
Good to hear it, Nashville. You can be accommodating when you want to be.
@BATTLE
I'm more accommodating to trained musicians than a captain with all the rhythm of a can of beans.
There's always percussion.
Can it before I get percussive.
*ALARM*
Just so you know, Nashville, I can always tell when you're thinking about having a drink.
Oh, yeah? Are you some sort of mind reader now?
Some sort, certainly. You have a tendency to leave your jars out when you're on the fence about it.
Oh yeah? How did you find that out? Have you been spying into my room?
I can smell it two decks away, and when I get near I can see the paint around your door peeling.
Is that what that is? I always just thought there were some issues with the sea air.

Fields.MenuText: It's not the sea air if it's only happening in one place inside the ship.
Can you not feel your bulkhead corroding? I assumed that would sting.
I'm glad to know the crew don't come after it, at least. They'd be in the infirmary.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, well, hindsight is pretty perfect, isn't it? I wouldn't go around judging.
Moonshine typically numbs that kind of thing.
I had a few who tried it. They were brave souls, and I will miss them terribly.
Reminiscing aside, we're moving towards an engagement in a little under an hour. Sober up.
Consider it done, Cap. Takes more than a little white lightning to bruise a cruiser.
@BATTLE
Don't some of you Belles drink oil?
Probably. No accounting for taste.
Hey there, Captain! I have a bit of a favor to ask you.
Sure thing, Nashville. What can I do for my favorite cruiser?
You can stop patronizing me for a start. Second, I want to know more about tactics.
Sure thing. What about them? Pincer tactics, the hammer and anvil, that sort of thing?
Yes. All of that. What did it mean? Are there crabs and forges I need to worry about now? Seems we could solve one with another.
No, those are... Why do you want to learn about tactics, anyways? It didn't interest you before.
Because I don't know them, and they're important. Now are you going to help me or not?

Fields.MenuText: You might do better to find a different teacher. I have very specific experience.
Certainly. I tend to be considered an expert at such things.
I'm not sure I have time to teach you tactics. I sort of have a fleet to command.

Fields.DialogueText: I need very specific experience, so there we are.
And I tend to want to rust and blow away in the wind when you talk yourself up.
Well, find the time. Having an informed fleet only benefits you.
We'll have company before long. Why don't you consider this your first lesson?
@BATTLE
How about I show you how I do things, and you can take notes. You like boring stuff like that, last I checked.
How are the preparations for the incoming passengers coming?
You mean the band? I'm on top of it. We should be ready in time to pick them up.
Good to hear. This ought to get us a fair amount of positive press in America, and with the Allies.
Plus, I imagine we can get them to perform for the Fleet, and that will be helpful. Everyone likes a celebrity.
I don't really like the idea of relying on the charity of others for our next meal, Captain.
Neither do I, but that's where the Fleet is right now. We can only help others if they help us.
And if we start trying to make ourselves self-sufficient, other countries might pull their support.
Leverage. I still don't like it, Captain. That's shady stuff.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we don't have a choice. So shut up and soldier, soldier.
If we could do it differently, we would. But we have bigger problems than bureaucrats right now.
Shady stuff makes the world go round, Nashville. I'd suggest trying not to worry about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain. Remember, I can follow orders, but I don't have to be good at it.
Bureaucrats are more likely to kill us than the Morganas, Captain. I'd watch for them.
Sure, Captain. Whatever helps you sleep at night.
I hear the alarm. Time to expend some more desperately needed supplies.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I desperately need to blow things up. Looks like we've got ourselves a compromise.
Nashville! We have a Morgana fleet forming up to starboard! How soon will you be ready to fight?
Soon enough, Captain. I was just finishing moving my auxiliary still out of storage.
Why do you need your auxiliary still set up? Are you not making enough moonshine already?
Well, I want to make sure the band is supplied when they come aboard. I imagine they like a nip or two.
Oh, well, that's very thoughtful of you, Nashville. I'm sure they'll be appreciative.
I need some time to make sure it can run without anybody getting hurt, Captain. I'm not sure the piping is quite right.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to have to worry about your quarters exploding any more than I already do, Nashville.
Well, I'm glad you haven't seen the need to put it into full production for a long time, then.
That seems like an odd concern, but I can certainly defer to your experience with the issue.

Fields.DialogueText: Well you don't, Captain, because I'm moving it out onto the deck somewhere.
Well, it has been a rather interesting time, hasn't it? I normally only drink from boredom.
About time. I am the authority on the subject.
Well, get it squared away and then see to your people.
I'm on top of it, Captain.
@BATTLE
After dealing with these Morganas, of course.
Of course, of course. For the band's sake, don't make me drink my whole stash.
There you are, Nashville! Have I got a present for you!
I don't know, Captain. Have you got a present for me?
Since you asked, yes! Here, take a look!
What is this, a wooden suitcase?
No, open it up. Preferably on a table.
All right, then. Oh, you got me... a little checkerboard? Wait, what are these pieces?
It's a chess set. I traded one of the officers for it. I figured it would be good for learning tactics.
It's just a game. What is it supposed to do for me? We're in a real war.

Fields.MenuText: Chess was used to teach generals back during the Middle Ages.
It doesn't teach you specific tactics, but it teaches you to think ahead and anticipate.
Well, if you think you're going to lose, I can probably go trade back and find something fairer for you.

Fields.DialogueText: Well we aren't exactly in the Middle Ages anymore, are we? Still, I'll give it a shot.
Huh, All right. I suppose it's worth a shot at least. Maybe you'll learn something.
Hey now, don't be trying that on me. You know I'm going to whip you.
Glad to hear it. We have an engagement soon, but how about a game after that?
@BATTLE
Gotta keep you humble somehow. Let's roll.
We shouldn't be far from the rendezvous point for the band. How is everything?
Their living quarters are all set up, but I'm a little worried about the crew.
I'm not sure I understand what you're talking about. What's the issue?
After I did a concert for the crew, it was tough to shake the extra attention. So, I figure...
You figure what exactly?
The crew might bother the band a whole lot when they show up.
It only stands to reason that if they find a real band they'll spend the whole time trippin' over themselves to follow them.

Fields.MenuText: That's a good point, and we'll be on the lookout for it.
These are professional performers. I'd think they can handle themselves.
Why don't you handle that?

Fields.DialogueText: Glad to have you speaking sense, Captain.
I'd imagine so, but it does pay to be hospitable.
Oh, I was going to do that anyways, Captain. I don't want my crew getting out of hand.
Well, we still have a ways before we're there, so let's clear the Morganas out first.
We can cross that bridge when we come to it, after all. I might get a chance to slap down a crazed fan yet.
@BATTLE
Will they survive getting slapped down by a cruiser?
If they know what's good for them, they'll ask themselves that question.
Captain, are you ready for our inaugural round of chess?
Sure thing, Nashville. This should be a fun little competition, and a nice distraction.
If that's how you feel about getting your keister kicked off, far be it from me to judge.
You're talking an awful lot of trash for someone with no experience.
And what makes you think you have any chance of beating me, hmm?

Fields.MenuText: Well, I am nationally ranked back home, so I'm not exactly starting fresh.
I command the Fleet. Strategy is literally what I do for a living.
Because neither of us know what we're doing, so I'm just going to lie.

Fields.DialogueText: Wait, what!? I didn't agree to this.
Psh, none of these pieces even look like boats. You're out of your element.
What? That's underhanded, Captain. I'm almost impressed.
Let's get this show on the road, shall we?
What do you say we make it interesting? Add a little wager?
I'm interested, but hold that thought. Let's get to the bridge!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The longer you make me wait, the higher the stakes get...
How's your celebrity problem going? The crew still hounding you? I did my best to try and stem the tide.
Well, it's helping, but there are still loads of them slipping through the cracks.
And I'm worried it's only going to get worse from here. They're always asking about the new arrivals, too.
We made it clear that these folks aren't here to entertain the crew, right? That we're just giving them a lift?
We need to make it clear that these are guests, and not people they should expect to perform on demand.
I should see about getting my boys together as soon as I can. Maybe if I give a show, it'll take the crew's mind off their passengers.

Fields.MenuText: Don't forget to let me know if you do. It was my idea, after all, so I want to watch.
Good idea. Besides, playing is important to you, and I'd hate to think you weren't getting the chance.
As long as all of your tasks are still completed, remember.

Fields.DialogueText: So demanding, Captain! You're as bad as the little sneaks who come around for autographs.
It's not like I'll stop practicing when we have passengers.
Yes, yes, Captain. Don't fret so much. I'll make sure it happens.
All right, we have Morganas to deal with first. Then you can practice.
Oh, you're so generous, Captain. Nothing like a nice dustup before the music.
@BATTLE
All right, finally! The inaugural chess game between the two titans...
Between one titan and some sort of smaller, less impressive, normal-sized person.
Don't be so hard on yourself. You're almost an equal to me.
Make that one small, sad little person with no self-awareness whatsoever.
It must be very hard to ride your high horse with the decks heaving like this.
Unlike you, Captain, I was born with sea legs. Remember that.

Fields.MenuText: I remember that not too long ago, you thought tactics were edible.
I was born and raised for war, and you're a glorified valet.
I think you ought to put your fingers where your mouth is, musician.

Fields.DialogueText: You've been eating your words so long, you wouldn't know real food.
My life was actually important "before" our world was invaded. Funny how that works.
If I wanted to look like you, I'd put my foot there.
That's our cue to leave. Maybe less trash talk before the game, next time?
I'm fighting you on the battlefield I know best. Basic tactics, Cap. Try 'em.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You're just stalling because you know you'll lose.
If you can't take the heat, get out of Decatur County.
Nashville, get ready. We're about to reach the staging ground for picking up the musicians.
All right, I'll get ready. Why all the commotion? I've spent enough time preparing the bunks.
If they can find anything to complain about, I'll eat my guitar.
Well, they might complain a little bit about the incoming fire. It looks like the beach is under a Morgana blockade.
You don't say. Remind me again why we're risking our lives so some soldiers can have a show?

Fields.MenuText: This is a favor to the American government. There might come a time we're thankful for engendering a bit of good will.
Sometimes I forget this is your first war.
Because I said so, and I'm in command. If you have a problem, or don't trust me, then let me know.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so, but I could always play the show myself. That's the greatest will we'll ever engender.
I'm getting pretty tired of this "babe in the woods" thing you seem to have over me.
All right, Captain, sheesh. I said I'll get everything ready.
Just make sure you're ready for the approach. We want everyone loaded as soon as possible.
We aren't staying for the battle, Captain?
That's a job for coastal batteries and railway guns. But we're definitely going to get our piece.
@BATTLE
Just making sure. One can never be too prepared.
How are you doing, Nashville? It looked like maybe you took a hefty hit on the way in.
Think nothing of it, Captain. Just like any other scrape, I can dust myself off...
... but it would've been nice if the crew could have stopped gawking at our guests and got to work.
George Burns on top of the Rockettes!? You could have given us a little bit of warning, Captain.
They wanted to keep it as quiet as possible, as a surprise for the crew.
Well, it certainly surprised 'em!
All right, drop to the back of the column for the push out. We need you and your cargo safe.
Nothing doing, Captain. I'm here to fight, and I'm in fightin' form.

Fields.MenuText: I gave you an order, Nashville. This is more important than your pride.
If you say so, but I don't think you should be anywhere near the battle with our celebrities aboard.
You know that if you sink, the rest of your crew and your cargo die too, correct?

Fields.DialogueText: Come off it, Captain. We're here to fight, and we won't be glorified nursemaids.
If that's what you think, then just watch me send those nasty witches straight to hell.
I'm not the only one pushing for a fight, Captain. I think the crew want to show off for our guests.
Then get ready to bust through the Morgana line again. I want to hit the Morganas before they can react and form up.
Come on, fellas! We've got a real fight on our hands now!
@BATTLE
How are the performers settling in, Nashville? I hope they aren't too shaken.
Oh, don't you start, Captain. All the officers are behaving like mother hens, and the crew's moonstruck.
You'd think these poor farm boys had never seen a dance hall girl before.
To be fair, they probably haven't. And even if they had, they're sailors now. They're happy with their accommodations?
I've herded diplomats around, Captain. I know how to put on a luxury cruise for these folks.
I reckon they might even complain about things being too fancy if this keeps up. They did ask for a bigger practice space, though.

Fields.MenuText: Well, as amazing as your accommodations are, this isn't a concert hall, so they'll have to manage.
Idle hands are the devil's playthings. Find them somewhere to work to keep out of trouble.
They had better pray their lives stay boring. If they become interesting, we're all in trouble.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah! Good for them they are getting to see the Navy first. That way they'll have a good comparison.
I'll think about that, Captain. It'll likely pay to keep fraternization to a minimum.
I might have to make the crew's interesting. Otherwise we might have a mutiny on our hands.
Good point. Speaking of practicing our skills, we're steaming towards an engagement as we speak.
Right! I actually remember the briefing. Sort of.
@BATTLE
Blast the spooky ones.
See? I keep up.
Okay, we should have the next hour or so to ourselves. I think it's time to show you a bit about how it's done.
Please, Captain, don't embarrass yourself. There's no way you're going to even prove a challenge for me.
You're talking pretty big for someone who still doesn't know how all the pieces move.
No, I've got it. The horse goes in L's, the little castle goes in straight lines, and the silly hat goes diagonal.
The round tops are boring and the last two are the most important.
Can't say you're wrong. So, would you like to be white or black?
What kind of a question is that? What difference does it make?

Fields.MenuText: Have you actually read any of that book I got you? I'm sure it would help you significantly.
In that case, why don't I take black? It only seems fair.
For a moment there, I was worried this was going to be hard.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not reading a book about chess. That's almost as bad as having to play it.
No way. If you want to be black, then I want to be black. I'm onto you.
The minute you stop worrying is the minute I cloud up and rain all over you.
*ALARM*
You just got lucky, Captain. And these Morganas just had their luck run out.
@BATTLE
Are you sure you aren't just setting the alarm off to get out of losing?
You have no idea how close I've come to ripping that damn squawk box out myself.
Oh, for-! These waters are supposed to be clear.
Nashville, I've been getting reports that you've had trouble with repairs over the past few days.
Not trouble, exactly, but it seems like the crew's a bit more easily distracted than they ought to be.
Seems like they barely have to pick up a welding torch, and a few inquisitive young ladies wander up to ask questions.
I assume the crew are only too happy to answer them?
Exactly. And when I tell them to get back to work, all I get are those dang eyelash flutters and assurances that they aren't hurtin' nothin'.
I could take one or the other, but the crew's a bit too busy making moon eyes to do anything, and the girls like the uniforms.

Fields.MenuText: Have you considered confining the passengers to their quarters for safety?
I know how to fix this. Where do I find a welding torch?
This sounds like a real hazard. I can have them moved onto another ship if you'd prefer.

Fields.DialogueText: I've tried that already, and all I get are big, strong sailors offering to protect them.
Oh, now, don't you start, Captain. I've had just about enough of this.
No, no, I can handle showbiz types. It's just going to take some doing.
Well, I'm glad you're on top of this issue. Please let me know if you need anything at all.
Will do, Captain. For now, I think that pack of Morganas needs our attention.
@BATTLE
Captain! There you are. I'm starting to think I do have a problem that I could use your help with.
Do tell. Are the show girls causing trouble?
Well, yes and no. It turns out my crew has sort of been talking up the whole "concert" thing.
Oh, no.
Yeah, and now they want me to do a show with them, "to entertain the boys and girls in the Fleet."
If word of that got out, we'd have every crew in the Fleet clamoring for seats.
Man, I didn't even think of that. I really don't want to go through that whole dog and pony show again.

Fields.MenuText: We need to come up with some way to convince these people that your show wasn't worth seeing.
Is there anything we can do to distract them? Take their minds off of it?
I think we might need to come up with a suitable reprimand for your crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Good luck with that, Captain. I am the best there's ever been.
Good luck with that, Captain. As far as I can tell, they're more than distracted enough already.
I'm already working on that, Captain. I'll make them regret this.
Well, at least we know your performance hasn't dulled in their minds.
There's an alarm. I'll give those Morganas a show to remember as well!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
This time for sure. I have the ultimate plan for our first game of chess.
Not have it be interrupted after we set up, but just before we start the actual game?
No! I got little pieces of adhesive, and we'll use them to hold the pieces in place when we're not here.
So, what, we'll just play whenever both of us have a minute? I'm not sure how that's better.
Actually, I was just going to leave the board set up so we could each take our turn whenever we get the chance.
We don't really both need to be here for the game to progress a single turn.
Well, if you want to do it that way, I guess we can. I was hoping to actually play against you, though.

Fields.MenuText: All right, we can hold off for when both of us can be in the same room. It's slower, but I see your point.
We can still talk about it when we're not here. Just play a bit faster.
How about we do it in whichever fashion you find most comfortable.

Fields.DialogueText: I assumed you would. You're not nearly as stupid as you look, after all.
I don't like it. What if you need to ask how a piece moves again before you play?
Perfect. And I just told you which fashion I find most comfortable, so there.
Is that really an alarm? Again?
We'll take the first turn afterwards. Now let's go deal with this interruption.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Oh, Captain - it's worse than I thought it would be.
What are you talking about, Nashville? You've performed before. This shouldn't be a problem for you.
It's not that, Captain! Those damn pretty girls got me a costume!
I never really figured you for the sort to put on a show when you performed.
You haven't even seen it, Captain! And they're talking about taking me out on stage with them!
What, as part of their chorus girl routine?
Exactly! I can't go prancing around like one of those dance hall girls! What would my mother think?
You have a mother?
Not the point, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Well there's nothing doing. You're definitely going to have to put that costume on.
You don't have to wear anything you don't have to.
The crew will be crushed when they find out you aren't going to do it.

Fields.DialogueText: Go to hell, Captain.
Damn right I don't, and I don't intend to either.
The crew will also be crushed if I drop a shell on them for being perverts.
Point taken. Why don't we find you some nice Morganas to take that aggression out on.
Bring them on, Captain. I feel like blasting some revealing costumes right about now.
@BATTLE
I have to say, the adhesive was a good idea. Our game is actually progressing.
Not for much longer, though. I've got you on the ropes.
No you don't. All of your pieces are out of position, and I'm about to swoop in.
Swoop away, but I think you'll find me waiting for you.
Speaking of, are you starting to see what I was saying about tactics?
I think so. It's hard to remember what everything does, but I know it's important, so I'm trying.

Fields.MenuText: That's the spirit, Nashville. It doesn't come easily to everyone, so you just need to keep at it.
I've seen you get better even over the course of this game, so I have a lot of hope for you.
Don't get too cocky. Your defeat is inevitable and coming swiftly.

Fields.DialogueText: Enough with the cheering, Captain. I'm doing this because I want to, not because you're sappy about it.
Don't patronize me, Captain. I'm going to see you destroyed.
We'll see about that when you're eating those words.
We'll be in range of our next Morgana combat in a few minutes. We'll pick up again soon. Be thinking about your next move.
I'll fight the battle in front of me, Captain. I tend to win that way.
@BATTLE
Well, how'd they take the news?
Devastated, every one of them. Falling all over themselves to tell me how good I'd look in it, and how much the crew'd like it.
I don't give a damn what the crew likes. We're here to fight a damn war, not win a beauty pageant.
A sentiment I can get behind. Morale is important, but the morale of a ten-thousand-ton cruiser a little more so.
Are you calling me fat, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: I can't win, can I?
You're not fat. You've just got a large superstructure to support your armament.
I know better than to call you anything, Nashville.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm just joshing with you, Captain.
Damn right, I'm a sturdy girl. I work for a living, after all.
You're well trained, I'll give you that.
How are you feeling about the show?
I'm not sure, now that I ain't the center of attention.
Well, we can cross that canal when we come to it. In the meantime, I think we're coming close to an engagement.
@BATTLE
Now there's a show I don't mind sharing the spotlight in.
But, no. No, you can't. Not ever.
Let the crews know to batten down, because we'll be pushing into Morgana-held territory soon.
Finally! I can't wait to get these civilians off of my decks.
And here I thought the show went pretty well. Everyone seemed to like it.
Everyone liked the Rockettes. Do you know what the number one comment I got was?
What an excellent musical accompaniment you provided?
Nope! It was "Why didn't you wear the costume, Nashville?"
The next one of those twits to ask me that and smile... that stupid grin is getting tossed overboard!

Fields.MenuText: Do you want me to do something about it?
If it makes you feel any better, I didn't think that the whole time the show was going on.
I'm surprised they noticed that with all the Rockettes out there. It's almost flattering, don't you think?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I'll do something about it, even if I have to deck one of those perverts.
That actually does, Captain. Thanks. Good to know someone remembers I'm a fighter.
You know exactly the wrong thing to say to a lady, don't you, Captain?
We must have hit a picket. Get the crew to battle stations.
Good. Time to remind everyone I am a creature to be feared.
@BATTLE
Sense that? Of course you don't, because you're not a Belle... Morganas, Cap.
So, what do you think?
It looks simple enough. They're over there, and we're over here. We could just smash through.
All right, but what do you think? What would you do?
I don't know, but it sort of reminds me of that thing you did with your little castle piece.
Maybe we ought to trick them into trying to come for us, so we hit them while they're spread out.
That's a pretty sound plan. It's called a feint, by the way.
I didn't faint! I just didn't see it coming, is all.

Fields.MenuText: No, a feint is when... never mind.
Right, fair enough. Still, I like your plan, so we're going to do it.
I certainly rooked you, that's for sure.

Fields.DialogueText: I know what fainting is, Captain. Just because I've never done it doesn't make me ignorant.
Good. I'm the best at plans. Make sure you really sell it, like I've been doing.
Why are you smiling like that, Captain? That's a weird face to pull.
I'll go make sure everyone gets into position.
@BATTLE
Time to make these hags faint.
Have the entertainers been safely offloaded?
Them and their supplies, Captain. They're headed inland with some trucks, looking for the front lines.
I can tell you, I'm more than glad to see the back of them. They were nothing but trouble.
I think you might be one of the few of us who think so, Nashville. The crew sure seemed to like them.
The crew are idiots, Captain. But you keep proving that you aren't, and I appreciate that about you.
Please. I have a high enough opinion of myself already, and I don't want my head to burst.
No danger of that, Captain. Your head's big enough to fit your whole ego in and let it rattle around.

Fields.MenuText: All right, now you're just being mean. I know for a fact my ego fits snugly inside.
I'd say look who's talking, but there isn't a mirror big enough to reflect your swelled head.
If this is what I get for being gracious, I'm going to have to destroy you at chess.

Fields.DialogueText: Just like I did into that costume. I kept it, by the by. A nice souvenir. And no, you don't get to see.
Good thing I ain't the kind of girl who moons around staring at mirrors. You'll have to tell me what that's like.
You're more than welcome to try, but I've got you pinned. You just don't know it yet.
You're a tough one, all right. I hope you keep the Morganas on their toes the same way you do me.
I'm not half so hard on them, Captain. And call me Nash.
You got it, Nash. Care to rip some Morganas apart with me and my huge ego?
It ought to draw their fire. Let's go!
